title: When People are *Floods*: Analyzing Dehumanizing Metaphors in Immigration Discourse with Large Language Models
author: Julia Mendelsohn (University of Chicago), Ceren Budak (University of Michigan), ...
background: Analyzing how metaphorical language in immigration discourse on social media influences public perception and engagement.
contribution: This paper introduces a computational approach for measuring metaphor in political discourse, focusing on immigration, revealing the impact of metaphorical framing on public attitudes.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods largely focused on word-level metaphor detection or lacked attention to broader contextual signals.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work combines word-level outputs from Large Language Models (LLMs) with document embeddings to assess metaphor both at the word and discourse levels.

key_innovation: The integration of both lexical and discourse-level analysis provides a more nuanced understanding of metaphor usage in social media.
real_world_impact: Highlights how metaphorical language can substantially affect public opinion and influence political discourse, which has implications for social justice and policy-making.
limitations: No mention of limitations in handling various metaphorical contexts or potential biases in language models used.

new_terms.discourse-level metaphor: **Discourse-level metaphor** refers to metaphors that are understood not just through single words but through the broader context of how language is used in discourse.
